Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Effects of Within- and Cross-language Ambiguity on Word Learning and Processing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The majority of people in the world are bilingual, which gives importance to our ability to understand how bilinguals and language learners process semantically-ambiguous words both within and across languages. Cross-language translation ambiguity occurs when a word in one language has more than one translation in another language. Previous research indicates that within- and cross-language ambiguity both affect the learning and processing of words in the first language (L1) and in the second language (L2). However, little research has explored how the similarity in meaning between ambiguous words' meanings affects the acquisition and processing of semantically-ambiguous words and meanings in L1 and L2.

Under the direction of Dr. Tokowicz, Chelsea Eddington will examine these issues in three event related potential/behavioral experiments. Experiment 1 will examine how semantic similarity impacts the learning of novel meanings for previously-known unambiguous word forms. Memory and semantic priming tasks will test how semantic similarity between the words' novel and old meanings affects the learning and processing of these words. Experiment 2 will examine how semantic similarity of L2 (German) vocabulary affects the learning and processing of these words using vocabulary tests and a semantic relatedness task. Experiment 3 will examine how learners of German extend meanings from ambiguous English words to German vocabulary words by teaching participants only one translation that corresponds to one meaning of semantically-ambiguous words. Learners' semantic processing of the words will be assessed using a translation-recognition task.

The results of this study will provide a better understanding of how monolinguals and L2 learners process and learn semantically-ambiguous words, and will inform models of monolingual and bilingual semantic memory. The project will also support the scientific training of a promising linguistic scholar.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A large portion of words in the English language are semantically ambiguous in that they have more than one meaning (e.g., trunk). Sometimes within-language semantic ambiguity results in translation ambiguity, which occurs when a word in one language can be translated into more than one translation in another language. Both semantic ambiguity and translation ambiguity affect processing in the native language and a later-learned second language (e.g., Armstrong & Plaut, 2008; Boada, Sánchez-Casas, Gavilán, García-Albea, & Tokowicz, 2013; Eddington & Tokowicz, 2013). Despite extensive research on semantic ambiguity, relatively little research has investigated these factors in bilinguals and early second language learners. The overarching goal of the proposed research is to examine within and cross-language ambiguity with respect to interconnections between words and their meanings. Specifically, the proposed research will investigate factors that influence the processing and learning of ambiguous words within and across languages.

 

To investigate these issues, we examined how semantic similarity (e.g., wrapping paper and literary paper are more related than dog's bark and tree bark) impacts the learning of novel meanings for known words. In our first experiment, we did this by teaching native English speakers novel meanings that were related or unrelated to the known meaning of vocabulary words. We found that participants recalled more meanings for vocabulary words with novel related meanings than unrelated meanings, but no differences were found between related and unrelated meanings on a more sensitive language processing task. In our second experiment, we trained participants on a set of translation-ambiguous words that ranged in semantic similarity between the multiple translations of the English word. Participants were slower and less accurate at recalling and translating words that had less related translations (e.g., Trunk – Rüssel (elephant), Kofferraum (car)) than words with more related translations (e.g., Sheet – Laken (bed), Blatt (paper)). In our third experiment, we examined how second language learners mapped meanings from ambiguous English words to second language vocabulary by teaching participants only one translation that corresponded to one meaning of a semantically-ambiguous word (e.g., Trunk – Rüssel (elephant)). We found that learners map all senses of a word with multiple related meanings (e.g., sheet—bed/paper) to novel second language vocabulary but only mapped the trained meaning of an ambiguous word with multiple unrelated meanings (trunk—elephant/car) to novel second language vocabulary.

In sum, then, our project provides evidence that meaning similarity of ambiguous words impacts vocabulary learning in a first and second language. Our findings support previous theories in meaning ambiguity resolution in the field of psycholinguistics. This project extends previous research on meaning ambiguity by investigating how meaning frequency and meaning similarity interact in a vocabulary learning paradigm. Additionally, we found that our second language vocabulary training methods, which highly emphasized the meaning(s) of the vocabulary, led to successful learning of both word forms and word meanings for ambiguous and unambiguous words.

The broader impacts of this study include gaining a better understanding of how bilinguals, monolinguals, and second language learners process and learn semantically-ambiguous words. Notably, the majority of people in the world are bilingual, therefore it is important to understand how bilinguals process semantically-ambiguous words both within and across languages. In addition to bilingualism, learning a second language has become more important as international relations and global connections grow. Therefore, it is also important to obtain a better understanding of how different types of words are learned and processed in a first and second language. Importantly, this research has also provided opportunities to train undergraduates in research, including students from underrepresented groups. These undergraduate research assistants helped with running participants and coding participant responses that, in turn, gave these students experience with experimental software and the research process. Research assistants also participated in bi-weekly lab meetings, read and discussed primary research in these meetings, and presented their research in the Psychology Department's annual undergraduate poster session.
